#Usage of the Base64 encoding function.

= Introduction =

The base64_encode function is a very simple implementation, which is easy to use. 
<br/>
*Function:* <code>char `*` b64_encode(char `*`in, int l); </code>
The first argument is a char pointer to the string we want to encode, the second is the length of the string to encode. As a result this function returns a pointer to the encoded string.
<br/>
See the following example code for a usage example.<br/>

= Example =
Here, we take the first argument as the input for our encoding function and print the resulting encoded string.
<code>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

// The header, we need for the encode function
#include "base64.h"

int main()
{
    char `*`buf;
    buf `=` malloc(strlen(`argv[1]`));

    // The encoding function.
    buf = b64_encode(`argv[1], strlen(argv[1]`));

    // Let's print origin and decoded message
    printf("Origin: %s\nDecoded: %s\n", `argv[1]`, buf);

    // Clean up and leave...
    free(buf);
    return 0;
}
</code>
